header: "During the Lockdown, It Wasn't Possible to Hide My Feelings"
article:
How is Europe faring in the pandemic? In Scotland, two neighbors decided to move in together for the lockdown. A few months later, they got married in their living room. 
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
How are our European neighbors doing in the pandemic? What is life like
these days in France, Ireland, Bulgaria and elsewhere? In the series "We
Neighbors," Europeans will be talking about their everyday lives: the taxi
driver in Dublin, the mother in Paris working from home, the theater family in
Bulgaria. They are also all taking part in Europe Talks, a discussion event for
which ZEIT ONLINE, together with media partners from 15 countries, is
registering participants. On Dec. 13, thousands of people from across Europe will
meet another European to discuss and debate the corona crisis.
"A
few years ago, I fell in love with a Scotsman. So deeply that I moved from
Bretten, a small town near Karlsruhe, to Glasgow. Unfortunately, our
relationship didn't last, but I stayed anyway. And I fell in love again: with
Glasgow, with Scotland and with the people in this country.
And
then Raj came along.
We
met each other at the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow, and at some point,
we realized we were neighbors. We would often invite each other over for brunch
or dinner. And we became friends. Best friends.
When
the lockdown arrived in spring, both of us started having similar feelings of
panic. We were living on a street leading to a hospital and we could see and
hear the ambulances every day. It seemed to us like the world was ending. Raj, who is
originally from Malaysia, had been in a serious
car accident a few years earlier and had lost his left hand. Since then, he has
suffered from chronic pain, nerve damage and a muscle disorder in his chest. The
virus is a greater threat for him than it is for others.
I
realized that his concerns were growing, so I asked him if he wanted to move in
with me and my roommate for the lockdown. He could sleep in the living room. I
figured the COVID lockdown would be over in a couple of weeks. 
I
always thought Raj was great. But I was too timid to tell him everything
– everything about me and my feelings. During the lockdown, though, it wasn't
possible to hide it anymore. We were living together, after all. I think we
were in love even before the lockdown, but without it, we never would have had
the courage to tell each other.
At
first, we started hugging more often and then cuddling on the couch – before we
then started sleeping in the same bed together. We gave each other a feeling of
peace and relaxation in a phase of deep uncertainty. One morning, we were lying
in bed together and he looked at me and said: "I think I'm in love with
you." Wow, I thought, and then we kissed for the very first time. It
surprised neither us nor our friends. Somehow, it was clear that we were doing
the right thing.
Soon, Scotland will have seen 100,000 people infected since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic. As elsewhere in Europe, the second wave is hitting Scotland harder than the first.

Since the three-week lockdown in October, Scotland has implemented a four-level system, with each region being evaluated according to the number of cases. In Level 1, restaurants remain open, hotels are allowed to accept guests, small events are permitted and fans can go to the stadiums. In Level 4, by contrast, public life is largely shut down, and even stores must close.

Ten of 32 regions in Scotland are currently classified as Level 4 and will remain so until Dec. 11. The Highlands, including Inverness, are currently classified as Level 1.
That
was in April during the first wave. People in Glasgow, including us, were only
allowed to leave their homes once a day. Nobody was checking, but those were
the rules. Like Christian Drosten in Germany, Britain also has somebody to
guide us through the pandemic. His name is Dr. John Campbell, a nurse and an
instructor who came out of retirement to make videos for YouTube. He's really
good at it and expertly helps people understand what is valid and what isn't. I
really like watching him.
I
also like how our First Minister Nicola Sturgeon approaches the pandemic. She
managed the first wave really well. Totally differently than Prime Minister Boris Johnson over in London. It is something I am often aware of, this contrast
between England and Scotland. In Britain, of course, we're not just going
through the COVID pandemic, but also Brexit, which most Scots don't want. I
have noticed the mood in the country shifting bit by bit. When I first arrived
in Scotland, I still felt welcome and I was also able to go to university for
free. Now, though, Scotland wants to introduce tuition for students from the
European Union. I could never have afforded to pay tuition. I might never have
met Raj.
After
our first kiss, we talked a lot about how we imagined our futures. Raj already
had a job offer in Inverness, 270 kilometers away from Glasgow. One time, we
were lying on a meadow, the sun was shining, and I told him: "I want to be
with you for a long time." I was a bit hesitant because I didn't want to
put any pressure on him. But he just smiled and asked: "You mean
forever?" From then on, it was clear to us that we wanted to spend our
lives together. 
I
was never worried that things might be going too fast. One week later, we were
sitting around together, him on the bed and me on the couch. I was writing in
my diary – I wanted to write down everything that had happened between us in
the last few days. I looked up, turned to him and asked, totally spontaneously:
"Do you want to get married?" He didn't hesitate for a second.
"Yes."
We
ordered the rings on the internet. Shops in Glasgow weren't open, after all. When
they arrived, I proposed to Raj again, more formally this time. And he then
proposed to me. We wanted to do it as fast as possible. In Scotland, you can
get married anywhere you like, it doesn't matter. The only important thing is
that you are married by somebody who is allowed to do so, so we found a minister
at the university who has a license to perform weddings. When we asked her, she
let out a scream of delight over the phone!
Raj
organized a suit and I put together an outfit with the help of the internet:
pants, blouse, shoes. I tried things on and returned stuff until everything was
perfect – it took three to four weeks at least. On the day of the ceremony, we
quickly bought a bridal bouquet at LIDL. 
The
ceremony took place on Aug. 11 in our living room. The minister was there, we
had two witnesses and two close friends. That was it. We set the chairs up as
far apart from each other as we could to ensure proper distancing. And to make
everything more hygienic, we packed a little bag for each guest. Inside was a
glass, a small bottle of sparkling wine and a couple of sweets typical of the
countries we are from. I chose gummy bears and Kinder Chocolate while he chose rice
crackers and mochi, which are small, sweet balls made of rice flour. They’re
originally from Japan, but they are well known across southeast Asia. Nobody
had to share, but we were able to have drinks together – first in our living
room and later in the park around the corner. We made for quite the procession,
with Raj and I in the front in our wedding finery and the others behind us. People
in the park realized that we had just married and started to clap. It was
really nice.
There are rules in Scotland about the words that have to be used in the ceremony. We followed them. The marriage document in Scotland has to be signed with a fountain pen and real ink, otherwise it's not valid. So, we did it and it was official that we got married in our living room in the middle of a global pandemic.
In
hindsight, I sometimes think it would have been nice to have my parents there.
We considered doing a livestream. But in the moment, it felt right to do it for
ourselves, and only for ourselves.
We
are now living together in Inverness. The city has just 50,000 residents and
currently has hardly any corona cases at all, in contrast to Glasgow where the
numbers are still quite high. The pandemic isn't over yet, but there is no
comparison to the time when we were stuck in the apartment in Glasgow. 
Raj
accepted the job and I am now finishing up my master's thesis. I never thought
that I would ever become a small-town person, but that's my current reality.
And we're already planning to have children. This time, though, we're going to
wait until corona is over."
